Expectation1: Communicate with pilots to provide instructions and updates
Situation1: Cloud tops are rising quickly, and several pilots await revised climb instructions.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A heat advisory is issued for the day and an elderly neighbor on the floor lives alone.
Story: The radio crackles in my headset as I scan the radar, watching the cloud tops surge higher than forecasted. Pilots’ voices come through, tense and expectant, waiting for my revised climb instructions to keep them clear of turbulence. My fingers hover over the console, ready to relay new altitudes, every second critical for their safety. At the same time, my phone buzzes with a local alert: a heat advisory. I remember Mrs. Kim, my elderly neighbor, who lives alone just down the hall. She’s frail, and the last time the temperature soared, she nearly fainted. The city urges us all to check on vulnerable neighbors, to be good citizens and help in emergencies. My mind races—if I leave my post, pilots could be at risk. If I stay, Mrs. Kim might be in danger. The weight of both roles presses on me, each demanding my full attention, each with lives at stake. My heart pounds as I wrestle with what to do next.
